Translation of 楚竹書・金縢(en) into English.

p.seg: Three years after king Wu had defeated Yin,
the king had been unhappy (=sick) for a long time.
The two dukes told the duke of Zhou saying:
"We will solemnly divine for the king."
The duke of Zhou said:
"We should not trouble my ancestors."
Duke Zhou then made three altars on the same (=one) sacrificial platform,
and made one sacrificial platform on the southern side,
Duke Zhou stood there,
holding a bi jade disk and wearing a gui tessera.
The scribe then put down on bamboo strips the prayer
announcing to the former kings:
"Your chief decendant Fa,
has met with harm (=sickness) and is violently ill,
if you have the request of (=if you want) the oldest son above (to serve in Heaven)
Your chief decendant Fa
is not as good as me, Dan;
I am good and clever and capable,
I have much talent and much skill,
I can serve the Spirits.
But he has been appointed in the Sovereign's hall,
extensively (i.e. everywhere) to possess the four quarters,
and thereby to establish your descendants on the earth here below
If you grant me this (that the king may recover),
I will (sacrificially) bury (for you) the bi jade disc and the gui tessera
If you do not grant (it) to me,
I will return with the bi jade disc and the gui tessera (without giving them to you)
The duke of Zhou then placed what he had given as tribute,
the persuasive speech of using himself to replace the king (in death)
in a metal bound coffer,
and ordered the men in charge saying:
"Don't dare mentioning it."
Then king Wu ascended (to Heaven= die),
king Cheng ascended to the throne while still young
Guan Shu and his brothers
then started spreading rumors in the state, saying:
"the duke will be unfair to the child (=usurp the throne of king Cheng)
The duke of Zhou then said to the two dukes (=duke Tai and duke Shao):
"If I don't [...] [correct them I shall]
[...] have nothing to bring when I will meet again our former kings [=I will be ashamed in front of my ancestors].
The duke of Zhou dwelled in the east for three years,
and the men of misfortune [the rebels, namely Wu Geng and Guan Shu and their allies] were apprehended,
afterwards the duke of Zhou then presented the king with a poem:
called "The owl of Zhou",
and yet the king would still not go to meet the duke (doubting his loyalty).
That year, in the autumn, when there was an abunfant harvest,
and they had not yet reaped it,
Heaven sent fast winds and thunders,
the grains therefore bent down,
great trees were uprooted.
The people in the state [...]
[...] (king Cheng) wore his ceremonial cap,
the daifu wore their court dress,
in order to open the metal-bound coffer.
The king got that by which the Duke of Zhou had offered himself as tribute
the persuasive speech to replace the king (in death)
The king asked the ones in charge (of the burial of the casket)
who said: "It is true.
Ah, the duke ordered us
not to dare to mention it."
The king spread the manuscript open and cried, saying:
"Formerly the duke toiled for the Royal house,
but I, young man, have not got to know it.
Now High Heaven has set in motion its terror,
in order to show the duke's virtue,
I, young man, should go in person to meet the duke
the rites of our Royal house also justify this.
When the king came out
to meet the duke going to the suburbs
that evening, Heaven turned the wind
and the grain so rose up,
In regard to all great trees which had been uprooted,
the two dukes ordered the people of the state
to earth them up all up again.
The year was greatly (ripe=) fruitful,
in the autumn there was a great harvest.
King Wu having got sick,
the duke of Zhou's decision whereby he used himself to replace him [was the reason why the Duke of Zhōu had the ambition to replace King Wǔ CH]
